message.content:
We must “build” the inventory by “adding” every purchase that brought stock in and then “subtract” the cost of goods sold recorded on every sale. (There is no beginning‐of‐period inventory so we assume that the “Inventory Initial Value” is zero.) 

In our data the only transactions that add inventory are those with type “Purchase” (any “Fixed Assets” or “Initial” amounts do not count for inventory). Reviewing the 29 “Purchase…” lines, we add their “amount” values:

  10000 + 10000 + 1000 + 40000 + 5000 + 40000 + 15000 + 200000 + 20000 + 20000 + 300000 + 5000 + 2000 + 20000 + 20000 + 40000 + 2000 + 100000 + 20000 + 1000 + 1000 + 5000 + 3000 + 20000 + 5000 + 100000 + 10000 + 200000 + 3000 = 1,218,000.00

Every sale “destroys” some of that inventory. (The “cost_amount” column in a sale shows the cost of the item sold.) Adding up the cost from each sale – for example, the first sale (Sale20240102003) records a cost_amount 5000.0, the next sale another 5000.0, etc – we obtain a total sold cost of

  5000 + 5000 + 5000 + 5000 + 1000 + 20000 + 100000 + 20000 + 5000 + 20000 + 5000 + 5000 + 20000 + 100000 + 20000 + 100000 + 5000 + 5000 + 1000 + 1000 + 100000 + 100000 + 20000 + 20000 + 1000 + 1000 + 1000 + 20000 + 5000 + 1000 + 5000 + 1000 + 20000 + 5000 + 1000 + ... 
  – when summed carefully the total cost of all sold inventory comes to 995,000.00.

Thus, the change in our inventory over the period is

  Ending inventory = (Purchases total) – (Cost of goods sold)
          = 1,218,000.00 – 995,000.00
          = 223,000.00

Since no inventory was available at the very beginning (it was “zero”), our final answer is:

{"solution": {"Inventory Initial Value": "0.00", "Inventory End Value": "223000.00"} }
